diff_hunk:
@@ -416,7 +416,8 @@ def load(name,
          extra_ldflags=None,
          extra_include_paths=None,
          build_directory=None,
-         verbose=False):
+         verbose=False,
body:
Those are examples for nvcc kernels though. This kind of CuDNN usage is just host code.

You can't link to cuda libraries without also running a cuda source through nvcc. If there is a situation where you just want to link to cuda libraries but you don't happen to be building a kernel, you would need this flag.
body_html:
Those are examples for nvcc kernels though. This kind of CuDNN usage is just host code.

You can't link to cuda libraries without also running a cuda source through nvcc. If there is a situation where you just want to link to cuda libraries but you don't happen to be building a kernel, you would need this flag.
body_text:
Those are examples for nvcc kernels though. This kind of CuDNN usage is just host code.
You can't link to cuda libraries without also running a cuda source through nvcc. If there is a situation where you just want to link to cuda libraries but you don't happen to be building a kernel, you would need this flag.
